A lot of cosmological lecturers seem to conflate the idea of expansion slowing or increasing or being critically balanced and “flat” with the idea of the geometry/topology of the universe.  I don’t see this as more than adding confusion.  This amounts to space-time having and ‘escape velocity’ based upon its mass density which is fair enough….but I do not see why this influences (of necessity) the 4D shape of the universe. A sphere (hypersphere) can expand too slowly, stop and crunch back OR expand too fast and get bigger forever..OR be critically just right to slow but never quite stop. ALL WITHOUT losing its hypersphere geometry…right?

Distant points should be at the same temperature, because…they were at the same point once=homogenous.  Flatness: I’m not convinced.  Time is the 4D version of an extra ‘distance’ direction…you can’t ignore it.  Over a long distance you see dilation (Red shift) kicking in=space-time curvature.  Remember volume (all of space) is the ‘surface’ on a hypersphere model…it looks flat because the curve is gentle, but the curve shows in the changing rate of time passage at extreme distance.  In the hypersphere model, space is the surface and time is the radius…both are inextricably linked and expand into the future from a single origin.  The hypersphere can still be modified with early inflation and either infinite expansion or eventual contraction, without changing its form or geometry/topology. The observable bit to us is most likely just a tiny patch on the 4D ‘surface’ and of course the expansion quickly provides a prevention to photons circumnavigating space.  This model is easier to accept than a truly ‘flat’ universe which has infinite volume and no large scale Space-time curvature (therefore no time curve at the observable limits…no Red Shift).  If I am wrong…what is it that doesn’t work with this curved model?

It depends on how you define “universe”. If you include available space rather than just the location of material substances, then the universe is not flat. Instead, it is extremely large (possibly infinitely large) in every direction. The Cambridge English Dictionary dictionary defines space as “everything that exists, especially all physical matter, including all the stars, planets, galaxies, etc”. However, the Collins English Dictionary defines universe as “the whole of space and all the stars, planets, and other forms of matter and energy in it”. Notice that the second definitions includes all of space.

There is another hypothesis that we should consider. The universe may seem flat from our perspective. Imagine if you could drive your car around the earth. Except for mountains and valleys the earth would seem to be pretty flat. Now imaging if you were in your car at the north pole and another car was there but pointed in the opposite direction.  Both cars start travelling due south, but in opposite directions. As they travel they would be getting further and further away from each other. Until they cross the equator. Even though they continue travelling away from their starting point, they are now traveling on a collision course with each other. In this hypothesis, even though the galaxies are travelling away from each other, eventually they will be collapsing on each other. And so it all begins all over. Infinitely.

I'm late to the party, but I had a question that I truly don't intend to be pedantic. As you said, the universe's "flatness" is determined by the critical density.  Too little mass and the universe is open, too much and it's closed.  So, does being flat require a critical density that is precise to the level of a single atom?  It seems that being flat requires a perfect balance, and even one atom more or less would tip that balance towards an open or closed configuration.  So, are we indeed perfectly flat, or are we merely approximately flat? And if the latter, then are we not, by definition, either open or closed?

Great video, but one minor quibble around 0:17: being at the critical density, or spatially flat, does not say anything about whether the Universe will expand forever or collapse back on itself. In fact if dark energy is a cosmological constant, our Universe will expand forever, even though it is spatially flat (i.e. at the critical density). The critical density comes from solving the Friedmann equation, which governs cosmological expansion, under the assumption that the energy density in spatial curvature is zero, meaning that contained in all the other components has to equal the total. The total energy density sets the value of the Hubble constant at present, which is an observed parameter, and so the Universe's being at critical density is just the statement that the total density of all species excluding curvature is enough to give rise to the observed present-day Hubble constant. The critical density is rho_crit = 3H_0^2/(8*Pi*G), H_0 = about 70 km/s/Mpc and G=Newton's constant. rho_crit is about 6 hydrogen atoms per cubic meter.

The question of whether it will expand forever or not hinges on the nature of dark energy, which we actually do not know with certainty. Dark energy is currently ~72% of the Universe, compared to matter (like us) at 4% and dark matter at ~24%. Note that dark matter and dark energy are totally different things; the similar names are just a coincidence, and as far as we know the two components do not inter-convert between each other.

If dark energy has equation of state (pressure/energy density) = -1, then the Universe will gradually asymptote to a perfectly exponential expansion (which is accelerated) and will continue that way forever. This is because the expansion of space will create more vacuum energy as occurs, maintaining the vacuum energy density as a constant. If dark energy has equation of state >-1, the Universe will dilute the dark energy as it expands, resulting in slower expansion relative to the previous case, though still accelerated. If the equation of state is <-1, then the Universe will end in a big rip.

I've always had issue with the big bang theory. The distances and time spans (which are same thing of course) are so vast in comparison to anything we’ve actually been able to measure, that even the brightest mathematicians can only really take an educated guess.

We really have no idea about the properties of matter in such a highly condensed state as the bang asserts, let alone how the laws function in such density. I feel that to simply assume they both behave anything like how we now obverse is simple foolishness.

Historically humans have been wrong on just about everything, and it’s quite possible that our assumptions of what we now believe the universe to be, may yet just be another large cluster in a group of many such clusters.

Theoretically: Galaxy, Super Cluster, Universe, Super Universe.. etc etc.. Red shift and advanced mathematics may not even be able to asses if there is anything outside of the current observable Universe, let alone be used as a tool to measure it.

Humans have (what I believe is) a mistaken tendency to state whatever is is that we now know as the facts, and science does have it's own pseudo religious views on what are and what aren't facts, but I always thought 'facts' were all relative and absolutely subject to change.

I cynically don't believe humanity will ever be able to see past the observable universe we now know, either due to dark matter, due to scale, or most likely to humanities seemingly soon to come extinction, but a bird’s eye view of human history may tell us this, that we have forever put limitation on what we view as the functioning, the size, and and the very laws of the universe, only to find that we vastly underestimated literally everything.

Neil DeGrass Tyson says the genetic difference between all of human knowledge and monkeys flinging poop is less than 1%. We have such a limited point of reference I think we have observed far too small a sample size of a gargantuan, possibly infinite Universe to have come to such conclusive theories. We are so finite compared to, and have seen so little of -the system we are trying to understand.

Imagine an ant pondering a world issue like global warming. With it's limited point of reference and relatively short range sensory technology it would be impossible for it to develop coherent theories because it would lack an understanding of the complex systems involved. We are no different, math can only take us so far and we will never have a concrete understanding without seeing the system that's being measured from all angles.

Astronomy is such a grand avenue of research it is more important than ever to remain objective and irresolute in this endeavor.

We have based a lot of our understanding of reality on the theories reached thus far (from our limited point of reference in the Universe mind you) and this is a dangerous concept when considering vast amounts of time.

If we're wrong about a fundamental truth of the Universe now, but our species happens to survive for thousands of more years evolving from the established "model of reality", how much will we have lead astray our progeny due to our current, limited calculations which we so readily accept as concrete principles?

There are a lot of ad hoc assumtptions made to validate the Bigbang Theory. Remember that Edwin Hubble himself was not convinced of the expansion of the universe he himself derived from the redshift discovery and measurements. Halton Arp (his apprentice) took it a lot further, becoming a leading expert in the field of Quasars (with apparent connections with galaxies). Why is that so special? Since thousands of qso's are visibly connected to parentgalaxies but have very different redshifts. And on the assumption that redshift means velocity (the further away the higher the redshift) the whole idea of an expanding universe is build. See what I mean.
These here mentioned inflatory stages (and other scifi-sounding actions) were ad hoc invented (mathematically 'proved')to fit the anomalous data trying to validify the timescales and therefore the whole model.

So there are serious doubts about this BigBangmodel in the first place, but in the media there is little or no attention for those that have a different view on the matter.

Ahh yes, General Relativity, that theory (and I mean that in the scientific sense, not the lay-definition understanding of the term) which seems to explain so much, yet at the same time has so many huge, glaring holes in it. Holes that have to be plugged by proposed forces like so-called "dark" matter and energy. Yes, Relativity is highly predictive, as we have seen over the course of the past 100 years, but does that mean that it just has to be the end-all, be-all theory of macro-physics? The observed phenomenon of the continuing expansion of spacetime doesn't "fit" with what Relativity says we should be seeing, so scientists have proposed "dark" forces that we cannot detect... isn't that basically the same approach that theists use when they shrug and say "God did it?" Perhaps it would behoove the physics community to start seriously questioning the absolute efficacy of Relativity, and start looking for a replacement. But alas, such an approach is tantamount to career suicide for a contemporary physicist, since so many of their predecessors - the tenured professors & such who staunchly guard the gateway to precious grant money - have staked their careers, reputations, and egos on the idea of Einstein's Relativity being infallible, absolutely correct, and unquestionable.
I'm not saying that old Uncle Albert was "wrong" in the binary sense of things, because Relativity does do a pretty fair job of explaining a majority of our observations... well, until you get down to the subatomic level, anyway. I'm saying that if you think of "truth" as a dartboard, with the bullseye being the absolute bedrock 100% correct truth, Einstein seems to have landed his shot about 15 degrees off-center.

Nonsense.

One way to avoid hitting the ground IS to shoot the arrow faster, which results in a 'flatter' trajectory. The arrow reaches the target distance faster, which allows less time for it to fall, hence a flatter trajectory. But any bowman will shoot the arrow as fast as he/she can. Whether hunting dear, humans, or targets, the point is to maximize the collision force, and minimize variance from the desired target point. So hit it hard, hit it fast. That is absolutely true on small scale, but when we talk about big enough distances that's not a sure thing. Why? Because gravity. We know light curves around large objects, and that's because gravity actually curves space, not because light is affected by gravity.
So in fact, the universe is not flat everywhere, it has small bumps created by matter. If the overall shape of the universe is flat, it just stretches infinitely, and it is speculated that matter will dissipate to a point when it basically disappears (the big freeze).
Now an interesting thought is what if it is not flat, and what if it is in fact closed, meaning that if you were to travel in any direction eventually you would end up in the same place you started. In this case, the universe could collapse on itself ending in the same state as before the big bang, possible in endless cycle of expansion and collapse. So far this is not, as i understand, probable, because as far as we can observe the universe is flat.
But what if the curvature is so subtle, so infinitesimal, that we can not actually observe it? Multiply that by the infinite size of the universe (if it is in fact infinite, because that's open for debate too), and you still get a curved universe, even though we will probably never observe it. The preferred analogy is that from an ant's point of view the earth will always seem flat, because it lacks perspective.
This is just my understanding so far on the matter, i'm no physicist, so please debate me if i got it wrong.

Exponential growth is NOT fast!! We really need to stop this misconception.

"Exponential growth" refers to how the growth rate changes over time -- it grows according to an exponential equation. Take a car, for example, moving according to the equation s=t. It takes 1 unit of time to run from position s=0 to s=1. Now another car moves according to s=2^t - 1. It also takes 1 unit of time to run from position s=0 to s=1. The average speed is the same! The difference is that the first one has constant speed and the second one starts really slow, but gets really fast at the end.

The reason why the horizon problem is solved by inflation is not because space-time grew faster, but because in the early moments it grew much slower than previously thought, making time for thermal equilibrium to be reached.

One nitpicky point: At 3:55 you say that "the longer an arrow has to travel to get to the target, the straighter you have to have initially shot it". This analogy needs either a rethink or a rewording. Given consistent gravitational force, any archer (or shooter) will tell you that the longer the projectile's flight duration, rather than shooting it straighter, one must shoot it at a steeper angle in order to hit the target.
If by "longer" you really meant "farther" or "longer distance", then shooting it faster so that it has a "straighter" (or "flatter") trajectory to the target makes sense. To clarify, the Hubble distance says the universe is 13.8 billion years old.  If the current model of string theory is true, the period of rapid expansion would have to have occurred over the estimated average distance between stars.  That would yield a universe that is much younger than the 13.8 current prediction.  We can however see 46 billion YEARS into the past so we know that the universe is more than that age.  To account for this discrepancy, some have argued that the fabric of space is expanding, however, this would yield a speed of light that is different depending on your relative speed when compared to the expansion of the fabric of space.  Local objects do not move apart based on the redshift  predictions because it has been argued that gravity holds them together.  The rate of expansion relative to the fabric of space would yield a speed of light relative to us which is different than the speed of light relative to stars which supposedly are moving apart.

So, from my previous interactions with this topic, I've run into one of the implications of a geometrically flat universe being that it has zero total energy.  And that being the case, it helps us understand how all the stuff that exists came to be; the universe could have occurred spontaneously, requiring no external input of energy, since when you add up all the energy, the total is precisely zero.
